phenotastic package¶

Submodules¶

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D module¶

class phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.AutoPhenotype(data=None, contour=None, mesh=None, pdata=None, ddata=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A python class for the automated extraction of SAM features in three dimensions from a stack of confocal microscope images.

AutoPhenotype is a python class for the automated extraction of features of a shoot apical meristem (SAM) from a stack of confocal microscope images. Its main features are:

*Extraction of the SAMs surface using active contour without edges (ACWE). *Separation of the SAMs features into primordiae and the meristem. *Evaluation of the features in terms of location, size and divergence angle.

data : 3D intensity array
Image data e.g. from .tif file.

tags : unused

contour : 3D boolean array
Contour generated from data.
mesh : vtkPolyData
Mesh generated from contour. Can contain curvature values.
features : list of vtkPolyData
The extracted features from mesh.
results : panda.DataFrame
The results of the evaluation operations (e.g. sphere fit). Also contains the number of points contained in each feature and its curvature. The number of rows is the number of primordia, whereas the number of columns depends on the number of evaluation operations performed. New results are appended.
clean_mesh()[source]¶

Extract largest connected set in self.mesh.

Can be used to reduce residues of the contour fit inside the meristem. Works only if residues are not connected (share at least one point with) the meristems surface.

No return :
Overwrites mesh.
clear(what)[source]¶

Clear specified attributes.

Attributes to be specified can be:
*’all’ *’data’ *’tags’ *’contour’ *’mesh’ *’features’ *’results’

Specified attributes are reset into initial condition.

what :

compute_normals()[source]¶
contour_fit(weighting, iterate_smooth)[source]¶

Run several full iterations of the morphological Chan-Vese method.

Implementation of Equation 32 in Marquez-Neila et al. 2014. (DOI: 10.1109/TPAMI.2013.106).

iterations : int
Number of times, the Chan-Vese Method is iterated.
weighting : float
Ratio of the weightings of the outside and inside contour.
iterate_smooth : int
Number of times, the smoothing operation is performed during one iteration.
No return :
overwrite contour.
contour_fit_threshold(threshold=0.8, smooth_iterate=3)[source]¶

Generate contour fit via a threshold.

Uses a threshold based approach to generate the initial model of self.data. Threshold default is half of the images mean intensity; can be adjusted. Subsequently, the contour is smoothed.

threshold :
(Default value = .8)
smooth_iterate :
(Default value = 3)
contour_fit_two_stage(iterations1, weighting1, iterate_smooth1, iterations2, weighting2, iterate_smooth2, zoom_factor)[source]¶

Run a two staged contour fit. First fit is on down sampled image.

The generated contour from the first fit is then up sampled and is used as initial contour for the regular fit.

iterations1,2 : int
Number of times, the Chan-Vese Method is iterated. 1 ->
weighting1,2 : float
Ratio of the weightings of the outside and inside contour.
iterate_smooth1,2 : int
Number of times, the smoothing operation is performed during one iteration.

zoom_factor :

No return :
overwrite contour.

decimate_mesh(fraction)[source]¶

fraction :

feature_extraction(min_percent=1.0)[source]¶

Extract the SAM features from the sliced mesh.

Uses a vtk connectivity filter for the feature extraction. The points of the mesh are numbered. The method steps through the points (stepsize = total#ofPoints/res) and selects the connected surface in which the point lies. The selected surface is saved if:

*Its #ofPoints is larger than stepsize *It has not already been selected

(#ofPoints != #ofPoints(previous_iterations) )
min_percent :
(Default value = 1.)

reduce(factor=2, spline=False)[source]¶

Reduce the size of contour and data by the specified factor using slicing.

The method deletes the unused planes (keeps only every nth - n=factor). Can also use spline filters for up and downsampling.

factor : int if spline = False, float else
Specify the factor of reduction. (Default value = 2)
spline : boolean
  • False (default): use numpy slicing to reduce number of planes.
  • True: use spline interpolation for reducing / enlarging data and contour.
No return :
overwrite self.contour and self.data.
reset_results(keep=['points_in_feature'])[source]¶

Reset the result attribute.

Results to be kept can be specified. Keeps points_in_feature by default. If all results should be deleted use keep = []

keep :
(Default value = [‘points_in_feature’])
save(where)[source]¶

Saves the all data stored in an AutoPhenotype Object.

Recognises whether or not data is available and saves only available. Note: it is advised to create a new folder for every save, since multiple files are created which always have the same name. The following files are saved (if avaliable):

*data.tif : processed input data (e.g. reduced) as .tif stack *contour.tif : contour of data as .tif stack *mesh.vtp : mesh as vtk .vtp data (readable with

vtk.vtkXMLPolyDataReader() )
*featuresX.vtp : features in same format as mesh.vtp. Each feature
is a separate file and X is a running number starting from 0.
*results.csv : the results from e.g. the spherical fit as .csv
data generated with pandas DataFrame.to_csv().

where :

Results are saved as .csv file.

set_contour_to_box()[source]¶

Set the contour attribute to a box.

The box consists of ones on the surfaces except the edges and the first plane on the first axis (axis = 0). The rest is zeros.

No return :
Overwrites contour.

smooth_contour(iterate=1)[source]¶

Smooth contour with ISoSI, SIoIS operators.

Uses the SIoIS and ISoSI operator of Marquez-Neila et al. 2014 (Section 3.5) to smooth the contour. At least one iteration after step is needed to get a good contour.

iterate :
(Default value = 1)

sphere_evaluation()[source]¶

Add several results to self.results.

Added results are:
*’sphere_x_rel’: x-location of the primordium relative to the
meristem.
*’sphere_y_rel’: y-location of the primordium relative to the
meristem.
*’sphere_z_rel’: z-location of the primordium relative to the
meristem.

*’sphere_volume’: Volume of the sphere *’sphere_R’: Distance of the primordium to the meristem. *’sphere_angle_raw’: Angle between the primordia in the y,z plane.

Zero is chosen to be z = 0 and y > 0.

*–results missing–

Note: List of results is newly sorted in a way that the row with index 0 is the meristem. The row label is changed accordingly.

No return :
Results are updated (see description).
sphere_fit()[source]¶

Fit spheres onto the features.

Iterates over the vtkPolyData objects in features and performs a least square fit of a sphere to each feature.

self.results : pd.DataFrame
Four additional rows in self.results: * sphere_x_abs: absolute x-coordinate of the center of the fitted sphere * sphere_y_abs: absolute y-coordinate of the center of the fitted sphere * sphere_z_abs: absolute z-coordinate of the center of the fitted sphere Note: absolute means in units of the coordinate system used in self.features.
step(weighting)[source]¶

Perform a single step of the morphological Chan-Vese evolution.

Implementation of the first two parts of Equation 32 in Marquez-Neila et al. 2014. (DOI: 10.1109/TPAMI.2013.106). The third part (smoothing) is implemented in the smooth_contour method.

weighting :

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.getedges(shape)[source]¶

Create a 3D numpy array with zeros on the edges and ones else.

Used to suppress the fitting of edges by the smooth() function (ISoSI operator mask).

shape : tuple with three components
Shape of the returned array
array : np.array
Three dimensional numpy array with zeros on the edges and ones else.
phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.getplanes(shape, invert=True)[source]¶

Create a 3D numpy array with zeros on the surface and ones else or the other way around.

Used as initial contour for the AutoPhenotype.step() method.

shape : tuple with three components
Shape of the returned array
invert : bool
  • True: Ones on surface, zeros else
  • False: Zeros on surface, ones else
array : np.array
Three dimensional numpy array with zeros on the surface and ones else or the other way around.
phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.rgb_list(N, firstcolor=(), lastcolor=(), s=1.0, v=1.0)[source]¶

Generate a list of N distinct RGB tuples.

The first and last entry of the list can be specified. The list will still have N entries. The range of each tuple entry is between 0. and 1. The list goes from red over green to blue and purple.

N : int
Number of colours.
RGB_tuples : tuple
Tuples of RGB colours

phenotastic.Meristem_Phenotyper_3D.sort_a_along_b(b, a)[source]¶

Return list ‘a’ sorted following the sorting of list ‘b’.

List ‘b’ is sorted from low to high values. Elements in ‘a’ follow the sorting in list ‘b’. Example: to array

a = [p,c,e,s,e,i,l]; b = [5,2,7,6,1,4,3] -> sort_a_along_b(a,b) = [e,c,l,i,p,s,e]; # and b would be [1,2,3,4,5,6,7]

b :

a :

phenotastic.domain_processing.merge_boas_distance(pdata, boas, bdata, distance)[source]¶

Merge basins of attraction based on their euclidian distance from one another.

Uses a KDTree to find closest points.

pdata : pandas.DataFrame

boas : np.ndarray

bdata : pandas.DataFrame

distance : float
Maximal allowed euclidean distance. Smaller distances than this will be merged.

phenotastic.file_processing.get_resolution(fobj)[source]¶

Returns resolution of the image in ZYX order.

The z-resolution must have been stored as imagej metadata under the name “spacing”. Similarly, the x, and y resolutions must exist as tifffile.tifffile.TiffTags entries as “‘“XResolution”’” and “YResolution” respectively. If these values cannot be found, a value of 1 for the corresponding dimension is returned.

fobj : tifffile.TiffFile

phenotastic.file_processing.set_metadata(fobj, metadata, mtype='imagej')[source]¶

Set file metadata.

fobj : tifffile.TiffFile
Input file.
metadata : dict
New metadata dictionary.
mtype : str, optional
Metadata type. Possible values are among others ‘lsm’ and ‘imagej’. (Default = ‘imagej’).

Missing but required values will be added when the file is saved if not contained in ultimate metadata. See @tiffsave.

No return. Modifies input file in place.

phenotastic.file_processing.tvf2si(fobj, reduce_dims=[])[source]¶

Convert a TiffFile to a SpatialImage.

fobj : tifffile.TiffFile
Input file.
reduce_dims : list
List of tuples setting what dimensions to reduce, and by what index, using np.take under the hood. First tuple index sets the index of the given axis, whereas the second tuple index sets the corresponding axis itself. An input array arr of shape (193, 3, 512, 512) using reduce_dims=[(2, 1)] therefore inputs the equivalent of arr[:,2,…] into the conversion.
simage : timagetk.components.SpatialImage
SpatialImage object.
class phenotastic.file_processing.tvfile(fname='', data=None, metadata=None)[source]¶

Bases: tifffile.tifffile.TiffFile

Namespace storing the corresponding file stream and attributes governing (array) data and metadata.

fname : str, optional
Path to the input file when loading.
data : numpy.ndarray, optional
File (intensity) data. Stored in ZCYX order by default.
metadata : dict, optional
File metadata.

tvfile.asarray() and tvfile.data are not guaranteed to give the same result, as tvfile.asarray() reads the input file path for data.

phenotastic.mesh_processing.ECFT(mesh, holesize=100.0, inplace=False)[source]¶

Perform ExtractLargest, Clean, FillHoles, and TriFilter operations in sequence.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
holesize : float, optional
Size of holes to fill. Default = 100.0.
inplace : bool, optional
Flag for performing operation in-place. Default = False.
new_mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh after operation. Returns None if inplace == True.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.correct_bad_mesh(mesh, verbose=True)[source]¶
Correct a bad (non-manifold) mesh with two methods:
  1. method removesmallcomponents from the pymeshfixpackage, and
  2. identifying leftover non-manifold edges and removing all the points in these.
mesh : vi.PolyData
Input mesh.
verbose : bool, optional
Flag to print out operation procedure.
  • Assumes a triangulated mesh.
  • Recalculation of cell and point attributes will have to be redone
  • All points in non-manifold edges will be removed. This could in principle be improved upon, since one point may be sufficient to create a manifold mesh.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.define_meristem(mesh, pdata, method='central_mass', res=(1, 1, 1), fluo=None)[source]¶

Determine which domain in the segmentation that corresponds to the meristem. Some methods are deprecated and should not be used.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
pdata : pd.DataFrame
Corresonding point data for input mesh.
method : str, optional
Method for defining the meristem to use. Default = ‘central_mass’.
res : 3-tuple, optional
Resolution of the dimensions. Default = (1,1,1).
fluo : np.ndarray, optional
Intensity matrix.
meristem, ccoord : int, 3-tuple
Domain index of the meristem, as well as the center coordinates using the given method.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.drop_skirt(mesh, maxdist)[source]¶

Downprojects the boundary to the lowest point in the z-direction.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
maxdist : float
Distance in z-direction from the lowest point in the mesh to consider.
new_mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh with boundary downprojected.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.fill_contour(contour, fill_xy=False, inplace=False)[source]¶

Fill contour by closing all the edges (except for the top one), and applying a binary fill-holes operation. Note that this causes some errors if there is significant curvature on the contour, since the above-signal is down-projected. This can cause some erronous sharp edges which ruin the contour.

Assumes first dimension being z, ordered bottom to top.

contour : np.ndarray
Contour to operate on.
fill_xy : bool, optional
Flag to also fill in the xy-plane. Note that this can fill actual holes that arise if for example two relatively distant primordia touch each other at a point that isn’t close to the meristem.
inplace : bool, optional
Flag to modify object in place.
new_contour : np.ndarray
Contour after modification. If inplace == True, nothing is returned.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.fit_paraboloid(data, init=[1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 0, 0, 0])[source]¶

Fit a paraboloid to arbitrarily oriented 3D data.

The paraboloid data can by oriented along an arbitrary axis – not necessarily x, y, z. The function rotates the data points and returns the rotation angles along the x, y, z axis.

Returns the parameters for a paraboloid along the z-axis. The angles can be used to correct the paraboloid for rotation.

Paraboloid equation : p1 * x**2. + p2 * y**2. + p3 * x + p4 * y + p5 = z

data : np.ndarray
Data to fit the paraboloid to.
init : 8-tuple
Initial parameters for the paraboloid.
popt : np.array
Parameters after optimisation.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.fit_paraboloid_mesh(mesh)[source]¶

Fit a paraboloid to a mesh.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to fit paraboloid to.
popt, apex : 8-tuple, 3-tuple
Parameters for the paraboloid, as well as the coordinates for the paraboloid apex.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.geodesic(mesh, ii, jj)[source]¶

Geodesic arc between two vertices on the input mesh.

Utilises Dikstra’s algorithm algorithm to compute this.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
ii : int
First point index.
jj : int
Second point index.

Requires manifold mesh.

arc : vi.PolyData
PolyData corresponding to the geodesic line between the two points.

phenotastic.mesh_processing.get_paraboloid_apex(p)[source]¶

Return the apex coordinates of a paraboloid.

Use the return of fit_paraboloid() to compute the apex of the paraboloid. The return is in the coordinate system of the data, meaning that the coordinates have been corrected for the rotation angles.

p : 8-tuple
Parameters defining the paraboloid.
coords : np.array
Coordinates for the paraboloid apex.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.remesh(mesh, npoints, subratio=10, max_iter=10000, holefill=100)[source]¶

Remesh the input PolyData.

Can be used to equalize the sizes of the triangles in the mesh.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
npoints : int
The number of vertices in the resulting mesh.
subratio : int, optional
TODO. Default = 10.
max_iter : int, optional
Maximal number of iterations before stopping. Default = 10000.
new_mesh : vi.PolyData
Resulting mesh.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.remesh_decimate(mesh, iters, upfactor=2, downfactor=0.5, verbose=True)[source]¶

Iterative remeshing/decimation.

Can be thought of as an alternative smoothing approach. The input mesh is remeshed with a factor times the original number of vertices, and then downsampled by another factor.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
iters : int
Number of iterations.
upfactor : float, optional
Factor with which to upsample. Default = 2.
downfactor : float, optional
Factor with which to downsample. Default = 0.5.
verbose : bool, optional
Flag for whether to print operation steps. Default = True.
mesh : vi.PolyData
Processed mesh.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.remove_bridges(mesh, verbose=True)[source]¶

Remove triangles where all vertices are part of the mesh.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
verbose : bool, optional
Flag to print processing steps.

Assumes triangulated mesh.

new_mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh after bridge removal.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.remove_normals(mesh, threshold_angle=0, flip=False)[source]¶

Remove points based on the point normal angle.

Currently only considering the polar angle.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh on which to operate.
threshold_angle : float, optional
Threshold for the polar angle (theta). Values smaller than this will be removed. Default = 0.
flip : bool, optional
Flag to flip normal orientation. Default = False.
new_mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh with the resulting vertices removed.
phenotastic.mesh_processing.remove_tongues(mesh, radius, threshold=6, threshold2=0.8, verbose=True)[source]¶

Remove “tongues” in mesh.

All boundary points within a given radius are considered. The ones where the fraction of the distance along the boundary, as divided by the euclidean distance, is greater than the given threshold. The second threshold compares the euclidean distance to the geodesic one, and removes the vertices in this if the threshold is met.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to operate on.
radius : float
Radius for boundary point neighbourhood.
threshold : float, optional
Threshold for fraction between boundary distance and euclidean distance. Default = 6.
threshold2 : float, optional
Threshold for fraction between boundary distance and geodesic distance. Default = 0.8.
mesh : vi.PolyData
Resulting mesh.

phenotastic.misc.get_prime_factors(n, primelist=None)[source]¶

Get a list of prime factors and corresponding powers.

>>> get_prime_factors(140) # 140 = 2^2 * 5^1 * 7^1
>>> Out[1]: [(2, 2), (5, 1), (7, 1)]

phenotastic.plot module¶

Created on Tue May 29 21:53:06 2018

@author: henrik

phenotastic.plot.PlotImage(arr, res=(1, 1, 1), offset=(0, 0, 0), mask=None, mesh=None, meshopacity=1, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot an intensity image with its mesh (optional).

arr : np.ndarray
Array defining dimensions of coordinate array
res : 3-tuple, optional
Resolution of the array in the three dimensions. Default = (1,1,1).
offset : 3-tuple, optional
Origin offset. Default = (0,0,0).
mask : np.ndarray, optional
Array of same dimension as arr. Specifies what values should (True) or shouldn’t be plotted. Default = None.
mesh : vi.PolyData, optional
PolyData mesh to plot along with the intensity array. Default = None.
meshopacity : float, optional
Opacity of the mesh.

Only 3D.

No return. Plots input array and mesh if given.

phenotastic.plot.PlotPointData(mesh, pdata, var='domain', boacoords=[], show_boundaries=False, bcolor='black', bpsize=10, blinewidth=10, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plot point data of mesh, with eventual domain boundaries and attractor maxima.

mesh : vi.PolyData
Mesh to plot.
pdata : pd.DataFrame
DataFrame containing the point data of the mesh.
var : str, optional
Variable in pdata to visualise. Default = ‘domain’.
boacoords : list, optional
List of the coordinates of potential basins of attraction. If given, will label the domain curvature maxima. Default = [].
show_boundaries : bool, optional
Show domain boundaries flag. Default = False.
bcolor : str, optional
Boundary color. Default = ‘black’.
bpsize : float, optional
Boundary point size. Default = 10.
blinewith : float, optional
Boundary line width. Default = 10.

No return. Plots input.

phenotastic.plot.coord_array(arr, res=(1, 1, 1), offset=(0, 0, 0))[source]¶

Resolution of the array in the three dimensions. Default = (1,1,1).
offset : 3-tuple, optional
Origin offset. Default = (0,0,0).

Only 3D.
